content.text: Carefully measure \(u\) and record the value
Place the screen near the lens. Move the screen away from the lens until a sharp image of the triangle is seen on the screen
Carefully measure \(d\), the distance between the illuminated triangle and the screen, and record the value
Calculate a value \(m\) for the magnification, using your answers to **(a)**(i) and **(a)**(iii), and the equation \(m = \frac{d - u}{u}\)
Measure \(h_{\mathrm{o}}\), the height of the illuminated triangle, and record the value
\(h_{\mathrm{o}} =\)
Measure \(h_{\mathrm{i}}\), the height of the sharp image on the screen, and record the value
\(h_{\mathrm{i}} =\)
Calculate \(M,\) another value for the magnification, using your answers to **(b)**(i) and **(b)**(ii), and the equation \(M = \frac{h_{\mathrm{i}}}{h_{\mathrm{o}}}\)
A student says that the values of \(m\) and \(M\) should be the same
State whether or not your findings support this. Justify your answer by reference to your results for \(m\) and \(M\)
statement
justification
In the space below, sketch the sharp image seen on the screen
Describe one difficulty you might have found when measuring the height of this image
State two precautions which you took to make the experiment reliable
In this experiment, you will determine the magnification produced by a converging lens
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
The distance \(u\) between the illuminated triangle and the lens has been set for you
**Do not** change this distance
Pour hot water into the beaker until it just covers the bulb of the upper thermometer. Do not stir the water for the rest of the experiment
Wait for about 30 seconds before taking any measurements
Start the stopclock and read both thermometers
In the top row of Table 2.1, record these temperatures
Record in the table the temperature \(\theta\) of each thermometer at 1 minute intervals until time \(t = 6\) minutes
Complete the column headings in the table
State in which position of the thermometer bulb the average rate of cooling is the justifu your answer by referring to your results
position
justification
What precaution do your results suggest should be taken when measuring the temperatures of liquids?
Explain how your results show that this is a sensible precaution
precaution
explanation
Another IGCSE student wants to repeat your experiment in order to check the results
Suggest two experimental conditions which should be kept the same
In this experiment, you will investigate how water cools
The thermometers have been set up in the clamps for you. **Do not** adjust the heights of the thermometers
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
On Fig. 3.1, draw the symbol for a voltmeter, connected to measure the potential difference between \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\)
Connect your voltmeter to the apparatus to measure the potential difference \(V\) between \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\)
Switch on. Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the potential difference \(V\) and the current \(I\) shown by the ammeter. Switch off
Reconnect the lamps between \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\) as shown in Fig. 3.2
Repeat steps (b)(i) and (b)(ii) for circuit 2
Reconnect the lamps between \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\) as shown in Fig. 3.3
Repeat steps (b)(i) and (b)(ii) for circuit 3
Calculate, and record in the table, the total resistance \(R\) of each combination of the lamps, using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
Complete the column headings in the table
If each of the lamps has the same resistance, the total resistance of the lamp circuit 3 should be twice the total resistance of the lamps in circuit 1
State whether your findings show this to be the case. Justify your answer by reference to your results
statement
justification
An IGCSE student wants to measure the potential difference across the lamp marked L in circuit 2
On the diagram for circuit 2, Fig. 3.2, show how a voltmeter should be connected to measure this potential difference
The resistance of a lamp is significantly affected by the temperature of its filament
Explain whether this might have affected the results of the experiment
In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of electric circuits with lamps con in different combinations
The apparatus has been set up for you as shown in Fig. 3.1
Measure, and record in the first row of Table 4.1, the height \(h\) of the pendulum bob above the bench
Pull the pendulum bob a small distance to one side, as shown in Fig. 4.2, and release it
It will oscillate backwards and forwards between \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\), as shown in Fig. 4.2. One complete oscillation is from \(\mathbf{A}\) to \(\mathbf{B}\) and back to \(\mathbf{A}\)
Measure the time \(t\) for 10 complete oscillations. Record this value in the table
Without changing the height of the clamp, adjust the string to shorten the pendulum by approximately \(10 \text{cm}\)
Repeat steps (a)(i) and (a)(ii)
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Figs. 4.1 and 4.2. The pendulum has already been set up for you
Fig. 4.2
For each value of height \(h\), calculate the time \(T\) for one complete oscillation the equation \(T = \frac{l}{10}\)
Record these values in the table
Calculate the values of \(T^2\) and record these in the table
Plot a graph of \(T^2 /s^2\) (y-axis) against \(h / \text{cm}\) (x-axis)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph
Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
Describe a precaution you took in order to measure \(h\) as accurately as possible may draw a diagram
In this experiment, you will investigate the oscillations of a pendulum
